FROM OB-GYN.NET:"Ablation does NOT provide reliable birth control, since ovulation still takes place as before, and the uterine lining may be receptive to a pregnancy. Second, pregnancy in general should not be elected after an ablation; in fact, it can be dangerous. The procedure can cause changes in the uterus that make pregnancy potentially hazardous to the mother, including possible complications such as uterine rupture and placenta accreta (a placenta that becomes "stuck" to the uterus and cannot be removed, causing potentially life-threatening bleeding). Because of the potential problems with future pregnancies, it is generally recommended that reliable birth control, including male or female sterilization, be considered in women who undergo ablations."---------------------------------------------------------------Here is a paragraph from the book, A Gynecologist's Second Opinion: The Questions and Answers You Need to Take Charge of Your Health by William H. Parker, M.D., with Rachel L. Parker, Contributions by Ingrid A. Rodi, M.D. and Amy E. Rosenman, M.D:"Once the lining cells of the uterus are destroyed by the procedure, there is no place for a developing fetus to attach within the uterus. If some cells remain following an ablation, there exists the rare possibility of pregnancy occuring. If pregnancy were to occur, termination would most likely be recommended as doctors are concerned that without adequate cells lining the inside of the uterus, the placenta would grow directly into the muscle wall of the uterus and take hold like the roots of a tree. As a result, the placenta would not be able to separate at the time of delivery, and hemorrhage could occur. This procedure is not a form of birth control and another method of birth control must still be used to avoid pregnancy."So it sounds like it can be very dangerous, still!

Hello everyone.  I had the ablation done in June of 2006 and in June of 2007 conceived.  I didn't realize I was pregnant because I had no symtoms other than feeling tired.  No breast tenderness or morning sickness.  I began gaining weight and my clothes weren't fitting and since I had 4 back to back pregnancies, I thought I had fybroid tumors.  My youngest son was 1 and my oldest was 6 so I was definitely done.  Well I scheduled an appointment to see why my stomach was looking so bloated and found out I was 13 weeks pregnant.  Three days later, I woke up in the middle of night in a pool of blood got up and went to the bathroom and dropped a large mass the size of my hand.  I was saddend because I had just come to terms with being pregnant. Went to the doctor in the morning and with vaginal ultrasound, discovered I was still pregnant.  I was put on bed rest until the bleeding stopped.  I continued to blead not heavy but light (one pad per day) but the blood turned from the bright red to dark red within 4 days after that episode.  I lightly shed the dark brownish colored blood until the fifth month and then didn't bleed anymore.  I am now 4 weeks from my due date and I am only experiencing leaking of some sort where I have to were a pantiliner everyday. It's clear but it's there everyday.  Baby has been monitored closely all pregnancy, and doctors haven't scheduled me for c-section, so as of right now, I am cleared for vaginal delivery like my previous 4.  That's been my experience, and all I can say is, I was too scared and having nightmares of dying or bleeding to death during delivery, and I turned all that worry and fear and placed it in the hands of almighty God.  He is the only one who has my life in His hands. No doctor, or research is greater than the creator of life Himself.  I took their knowledge and did my own research of my risks, and prayed faithfully that my body would not be subseptible to what research shows. I confessed daily that my uteris would be a great incubator for this baby and my body will supply the nutrients neccessary to carry full term.  Don't let fear overtake you especially durning an already risky pregnancy.  Stay calm, find peace however you can to make it through. It takes strength, faith and wisdom but it can be done. I am a living witness, and in 2 weeks, I will attend my first and only baby shower for the daughter I longed for for so many years, and now she is just 4 weeks away from meeting her family.  She is my miracle baby, when I gave up and wanted no more.  God is always in control, and although I will definitely so something more permanent after this birth, I feel blessed that I can be a testimony for other mothers going throught the same thing.Hope this helps you ladies.

I am 6 weeks and 4 days pregnant.  I had a vaginal ultrasound yesterday and everything looks fine so far.  I even heard my baby's heartbeat:)  ~ But, I had an ablation (for heavy bleeding) a little over 1 year ago.  I saw my obgyn today and will be going to see a high risk obgyn very soon to discuss options.  I am hoping she will say that things will be ok, but I just don't know.  I think that the thing that worries my doctor and me is that the placenta will most likely attach and grow into the uterus wall.  This can cause massive bleeding when the baby is born and can put lives at risk.  I am very scared about this possibility.  I have also read about other complications.  I recommend to anyone that wants to become pregnant to strongly consider doing so before having an ablation because there are just to many negative things that can happen.

I'm back to give an update!  Yesterday afternoon I went to the my doctor.  I had initiated the visit and the transvaginal ultrasound and sonogram.  I wanted to see the condition of my uterus 9 months post-op.  Ladies I am happy to report that 5 months after my doctor telling me to forget about having a child I am thrilled to say that I have been given the green light!!  And for those of you who don't feel like going to back to look at my desperate and sad post in April of this year - I had Novasure in December 07 because of terrible painful periods. I was 36 and thought I was done having children. Right after the procedure I met the man of my dreams and we wanted very much to have a child of our own.  I went to see my doctor in March and he said to forget about getting pregnant.  It was awful.  AWFUL!My uterus has completely regenerated itself - 8 days into my cycle I have an 8mm lining which is completely normal.  My uterus is plump and healthy.  I am still only having very light periods though (2 days of spotting).  My doc told me that if he hadn't done the ablation himself (in Dec 07) he would have never known I had it done.  I've never seen my doctor look or act the way he did yesterday - HE was glowing.  I think he was shocked and amazed and sincerely happy to me (us).  The positive energy coming from him amazing.Although my doc told me he thinks this was all a coincedence he told me that he would never tell anyone to underestimate the power of the mind.  I think it was that but mostly Gods will.But I will tell you what I did that I know played an important role in all of this - and that is my lifestyle - both before and after the procedure.  My healthy lifestyle has finally proven itself!!  :)  First - I DO NOT SMOKE.  Second - I have an extremely healthy diet (whole grains, lots of green leafy veggies such as KALE and fresh dark green salads with veggies, lots of fresh berries everyday - rassberries, blueberries, blackberries, strawberries,. and soy bean "edamame" - organic whenever possible and affordable).  I do not eat **** such as fried foods, overprocessed food, junk food, sugars.  Third - I take 400IU of Vitamin E everyday along with a multi-vitamin.  And the last thing - starting in July I started taking 3000mg of BROMELAIN per day (3 seperate doses on an EMPTY stomach) for the first two weeks of my cycle.  Bromelain can help thicken the uterine lining.  You do not want to take this more than 2 weeks at the beginning.  There was a lot of research involved on my part with regards to Bromelain.  All I can tell you is that after one go around with Bromelain I started having RED blood instead of pink blood during my "periods".We have an appointment with an IVF doctor Sept. 8.  I'll update everyone then!Good luck to everyone!  There IS hope!!

I'm doing well today.  I was actually able to set foot in my favorite Mexican restaurant today and not feel like throwing up!  For some reason when I am pregnant I just can't eat Mexican food, seafood or popcorn:(  To answer your question~ Before my ablation my periods were extremely heavy.  After the ablation I still had periods each month, but they were very manageable.  My doctor has done many ablation procedures, but I am the first one that has gotten pregnant after.  He sent me to Indianapolis within a week to see a maternal fetal health specialist.  She let me know that while it is a definite possibility that I will need a hysterectomy upon delivery, that she has had patients that have delivered vaginally.  I have an appointment tomorrow morning with my doctor here in town and another appointment in Indianapolis in 4 weeks.  They have done either a vaginal ultrasound or regular ultrasound at each appointment.  I will be having some sort of special ultrasound when I go back to Indianapolis.  I think the thing I am having trouble with right now is putting on weight.  The morning sickness has been a pain to deal with this time around.Well, I am going to take my dog on a walk before my kids arrive home from school.  Have a good afternoon everyone:)   ~~I would still recommend the ablation procedure, it was the only thing that helped me.  I just wish that we would have tried for this baby before we had the procedure done.  It would be a lot less scary.

My doctor also told me that he had ONE patient who got pregnant after ablation so far - just one.  She had a history of infertility - extremely heavy periods and opted for the ablation at the age of 40.  9 month later she got pregnant and went on  to have a healthy baby.

I know that they watched my uterus very carefully.  I had ultrasounds ever 4 weeks thru entire pregnancy.  They were watching the baies growth rate as well as to see if the placenta had developed an Accreta (which it had)  That is were the placenta grows so deep into the uteran wall that it cannot release at child birth.  Therefore they did a C section as well as a hysterectomy.  They also had me on moderate bed rest at end of the pregnancy to stop some preterm labor.  I know that my Dr. had consulted with a Dr. a the Mayo clinic thru entire pregnancy, because it was the first time he had this happen.  So maybe your Dr. can seek some advice as well.Good Luck

I am still here, just haven't been able to check the site. Any way to get these messages to come to my inbox?I am now 11 weeks pregnant and doing fine.  I have been to my OB and to a Specialist. I will be seeing them each monthly, so about every 2 weeks I see one or the other.  Neither practice has had a case of pregnancy after EA, but I feel confident with both of my Dr.'sI have had 2 ultrasounds and think I will have one every visit. They said everything looks good and the baby's heartbeat is good.  "Peanut" is also growing on schedule as expected.I think the majority of my worries lately have been over genetic issues as I will be 40 in less than 2 weeks. But after reading about Katie and baby Nathan, like most of you, I cried and asked myself "What will my family do if that happens to me?"  Will it have been worth it?   My specialist wants me to have the round of genetic tests done.  I told her that I was not willing to terminate for Down's or some other genetic issue, but she broke it down to me like this....   "What if you go through all of this and have a baby that only lasts a few days (Trisomy 18) or yet, what if you go through all of this, don't make it yourself and your husband has a baby that only lives 2 days."  It hit me then, but it really hits now.Jodi

Jody- I was pressured by my doc's as well for genetic testing due to the fact that I was 37.  I denied all testing.  The blood panels only tell you that there could be a chance, they are not definate.  I had a friend almost terminate a perfectly healthy son, due to that testing.  As for the amnio, I understood that there was only a 1 and 270 chance of Downs or other genetic problems, but the chance of miscarriage was 1 in a 100.  I figured I  had more chances of losing a healthy baby than finding out something was wrong.  Only you can decide whats right for you, I just wanted to offer a different perspective.

My Dr. already told me that they would have blood on hand as a precaution.  Did she know if the placenta was attached to the uterine wall?   I wish we could find out her Dr.'s name and location so that one of our Dr.'s could contact them.  Neither my OB or high risk have had a case so they are seeing me every two weeks and said we will be prepared for anything.I cried for hours yesterday about Katie and Nathan.  I could not stop thinking that it could happen to me. My husband would not be able to handle it and what about my kids?  I am trying to remember what Jewel said and keep praying for the best.  These are our little miracles and I want to think that God is giving us another chance but then look at Katie and Nathan.I wish there was a study we could look at to see the end results and percentages.  How could we compile our own "legitimate" study for others?  We can't always be sure that the info on a forum is 100% accurate with people dropping off for unknown reasons...we assume something happened to them, but heck maybe they just got rid of their internet?!I definatley agree that anyone trying to have a baby after EA should  re-think the situation.  Dr's should require permanent birth control in addition to the EA.  Not just recommend it.Jodi

I agree about the birth control.  Not only did my Dr. not recomend it, he made the ablation seem like a form of birth control.  I also had discussed the possibility of getting pregnant w/ another Dr. in the practice at a routine check up and she sad don't ever let it cross my mind, it could never happen!  Thats why I was sick for over a month before I decided to do a test.  Hopefully this opened their eyes at my practice.

I do believe with all my heart the babies are gifts from God.  Allthough I don't know why Katie and Nathan had to lose their lives.  I will never understand that.  I'm sure you are out of your mind with worry right now!  I will continue to pray for you and baby!  Do your Dr.'s think the clot could dissolve?  Whatever decisions you end up making will be what's best for you.... Just go one day at a time. ~ Julie

I am starting to second guess my dr! Any thoughts from anyone? He acts as if there is no need to see specialist yet, he says that all a specialist is needed for is to look at my placenta and that it is to early for that!  I am going to be 12 wks on Mon.  I see my dr on Tues and I am going to discuss one more time that for my own peace of mind I would like to see a specialist. The Maternal/Fetal clinic said I needed a referral from my OB!Holly is your specialist monitoring your Hematoma or just your OB?  I have one that has remained the same size. I am getting so confused and scared!  I know it is in Gods hands, I just want to make sure that I am receiving proper care if it is needed.  Does your specialist go a lot more in depth with everything?Any feedback from anyone on how soon you started seeing your specialist and how concerned your dr was would be greatly appreciated.

I didn't have a hematoma, so my case is different.  I never saw a specialist, but my Dr did consult with one on my condition.  Like I said in earlier posts, my Dr. never made me feel like things could be fatal.  He was very positive!  I guess ignorance was bliss for me.  I knew there could be risks to the baby though.  My Dr. just saw me more frequently than other pregancies I had had.  At about 20 weeks is when they started to regularly check my uterus with more in depth ultrasounds to check baby growth and placenta problems. Allthough the also gave vaginal ultasounds at every appointment as well.

I definitely think you should see a specialist just for the fact that you have had an ablation. The problem I am facing now is, on top of the ablation, my hematoma is so large, and even if it goes away, he said there could easily be more to come, and that puts this at even higher risk.Jewell, you are 100 percent correct when you say ignorance is bliss! My specialist seems so intelligent, yet he scared me to the point of considering a termination, which up until now, wasn't an option. While my doctor made me feel safe and secure, the specialist made me feel the opposite, but he also was telling me everything based on medical facts, and I have to weigh out the options.Plus the fact that my specailist just had a baby delivered at 24 weeks that didn't make it certainly doesn't help matters. I just wish I didn't know about it!!Also, I am a single mom raising my adopted daughter. She never sees her father, and she and I are extremely close. I am all that she has in this world. My son is 16, and from a different father, so if anything were to happen to me, she loses me, her home, her brother, everything. She would have to go live with a father who is 60 years old and never there, and a 28 year old stepmom that doesn't like her. Also, she doesn't know I am pregnant, and she will be SO excited when I tell her! What if the baby doesn't make it? She just wouldn't understand. This is all so frustrating!

I am at an absolute loss for words :o( I am so VERY Sorry to hear of this loss. As I site hear with tears strolling down my face, I now wonder WHAT AM I DOING?! I've known of the risks. Am I so selfish to have another baby that I put my own health at risk? Is it so selfish of me? Then I could actually leave the 2 I have behind with no mommy? OMG, this is so hard! How do I make a decision to terminate what God gave me? Yet how do I make a decision to stay with baby and possibly leave husband to do it for the rest of their lives? I don't know that reality has ever smacked me in the face the way it just did reading about Katie and Nathan. This is AWFUL news :o(Stacy

Holly- I can't imagine what you must be going thru!  You are in a tough position with your young daughter and son as well.  No matter what you decide to do, no one will judge you.  You make your decisions based on what you think is best for you and your family!  Just go one day at a time right now.

My Dr. referred me to a specialist immediately. I saw her about a  week after my first OB appt.  My OB was very positive and only very briefly discussed how things could go wrong and told us how we would be prepared.  The specialist was a little tougher, but even tougher with the genetic issues.  I will see them every month with 2 weeks between each appt.  I'm not sure exactly what more the specialist will do though her sonogram equipment was more high tech than that of my OB's.My other issue, which I'm not sure if I mentioned, is that I have 2 fibroids. One is the size of the baby and will, specialist said, grow along with the baby. She also said it appears to be dying from the inside out which can be painful if it does.  I have never had fibroids before so I'm not sure what to expect and how exactly it will affect the baby besides, Dr. said, vying for the same nutrients and blood the baby does.I did talk to my OB about the issues seen on here by the members and she didn't think the preterm labor was a result of having the EA, but other reasons.Jodi

One other thing my maternal fetal specialist said was that I have scar tissue scattered all over my uterus, which causes problems. He also said that if the baby does grow outside of my uterus, it could attach onto my bladder or rectum, which could have lifelong consequences. Sorry, I know that's so gross!Also, he said with the hematoma, which is quite large, my body's immune system will want to "clean up" the hematoma, but doesn't exactly know what it's attacking, and could eat away at the baby's sac. I don't know. He just kept saying so many scary things. I'm so confused. I'm going to talk to a rabbi tonight.

When they did the hysterectomy they found that my placenta had grown thru to the outside my uterus.  ( I think that's what you meant to say)  Thankfully no permanent consequences.  Try to remember your specialist has to tell you every possible thing that can go wrong, no matter how small the chances are, due to the liability issues.  What does he recommend?  Does he think you should terminate?  Or has he not said one way or another.

WOW! I know Dr's should tell us everything, but that's a bit much. You must be terrified right now. I wouldn't put a whole bunch of weight on some of that stuff. I mean really, I haven't heard all that. I have heard about the placenta and the way it can attach to the uterus. But my understanding is a hysterectomey at birth will resolve all thos issues. I know this is a scary time, trust me, I spent most of my morning crying over the "what could happen" What we should be spending our energy on is the "what could happen" in the positive lights! :o)I have 2 fibroids too. One on the inside of my uterus and one on the outside. I have NO idea what complications they may cause. I've just started thinking about that :o( But again, I can't change what is going on...so we now go to the positive side of things and pray we will all be ok!Stacy

He didn't say. I guess I have to make that choice.Stacy, I am so sorry I am being overly dramatic. I was feeling so positive before I went to him. You are right, he was definitely telling me worse case scenarios. I really am not good with all of that medical stuff. I hate hospitals, needles, drawing blood, all of that stuff. I am a nervous wreck!The fact of the matter is, we are all guinea pigs in this! I mean, they really don't know a whole lot about this whole thing. From  a legal stand point, the companies that make the ablation instruments should be more adament about making sure women get their tubes tied during the ablation.Once again, I am so glad I have you guys to talk to! I don't know what I'd do without you!
wowoowowow, congrats!

Honey, don't be sorry for being dramatic. I'm in the SAME shoes you are. I do feel like we are the guinea pigs. I'm not terribly upset about that, but at the same time, this is a VERY VERY scary time. We all want healthy babies and we all want to be healthy too! I'm not kidding, I freaked right out when I heard about Katie :o( I just don't see the sense in us dwelling over what could happen. We know some facts, but the rest is specualtion AND a case by case basis. We need to support each other thru each moment on this and report changes, findings etc to help educate ourselves. You hange in there. ANd ALWAYS remember no matter WHAT decisions you make thru this, NO ONE WILL JUDGE you! Not here anyway. :o)I started spotting this morning and I'm having some very mild cramps. I don't go to the doctor until Friday. I sure hope this is just part of the whole ordeal and everything is ok with the baby!Summer CONGRATULATIONS! You bring the hope we all so desperately need right now. Love and hug those beautiful babies for us :o)Stacy
What wonderful news!!  Congratulations! You have been blessed. This is wonderful news for all of us.Jodi

Have you called the dr.?  On a previous pregnancy I started spotting and my Dr. called me in to do an ultrasound and gave me progesterone. It helped save the baby.I am really surprised by the differences in how OB's treat different issues.  My friend's daughter started spotting and they called the Dr.  She was told to put her feet up.  She lost the baby at 10 weeks. This was a normal pregnancy.  Not trying to scare you further. Just wondering why some OB's do something and others don't.Jodi
I am so happy to hear you and babies are doing great!  Get lots of rest, and I hope you have some extra help with the little ones, especially while you are healing.  Finally some good news! ~ Julie

Summer~CONGRATULATIONS!!! I am so happy for you! And what adorable names! I wish we could put photos up! What a wonderful success story!Stacy~Thank you for your kind words. Also, I do believe that spotting is alot more common in our situation. I notice when i do too much, I will spot a little bit. Just take it easy. Even with normal prgnancies, spotting is usually fine the first two trimesters.

Summer, God bless you and your beautiful babies!!  CONGRATULATIONS.  Reading your story has made me realise that the dr can prepare us for the worst, its their job but our God is a MIGHTY, MERCIFUL AND POWERFUL GOD and all life is created by him!! How exciting no hysterectomy either!!!  You enjoy those babes!!Julie, Thank you once again for always being so positive!  We have decided to once again trust in the Lord a little more than yesterday!!!! This little miracle is in His hands no matter what a dr says! I have not used birthcontrol for 12 yrs and only had 3 pregnancies in that time of which I took fertility meds for the 1st one. AND MY DR TOLD ME A BABY WOULD NOT INPLANT IN MY UTERUS AFTER THE ABLATION. Drs are good but they are not GOD they read and learn just as we do.  I know we should now the "what if's" but right now I am sticking with my same OB because he has been very positive, is watching me weekly, has admitted we are in this together and that he has not dealt with a case like this so we wait and work together and he thinks, as we do, that God has plans we don't always 'plan' for.  It is all very scary, however I was eclamptic with my 1st and the complications there could have resulted in death as well.  My dr says I seem to like Russian Roullette :)  We have lost babies before and we know that God would not give us something he won't help us through!!  So we will wait and see.  I refuse to consume myself with stress and worry anymore, it is only harder on me and the baby!!Holly, stay positive!  Continue to get rest and pray!! I will be praying for you that everything gets better.  My 6 yr old prayed tonight that God doesn't let the baby in my tummy die. Which was really hard on me!  We have talked with her about it, in 6 yr old terms the best we could.  She knows that all our friends and family (church family too!) are praying for our health and thats about all we can do is trust in God.   We have lost many people close to us in the last 3 yrs, young and old and we have always tried to help her understand that God calls us home in His time not ours. It has allowed an open door to talk with her about knowing the Lord in a special and personal way and someday we will all meet again!!   Some think we are crazy letting her know so much about death, whether it be about my mom or our baby but she watched me grieve over the loss of my mom and I wanted her to understand the best she could that death was not scary but very sad for those of us left here.  If I did not have my FAITH I would be flippin crazy about life right now!!! God will get us each through this and has brought us all together for strength to help us get through it.  If it was not for this site I would not have heard anything positve!! Stay strong and we will all keep praying for everyone on this site and thanking God for each positive outcome we read about!!
Your babies are beautiful!  How much did they weigh at birth?  They look good sized for being a few weeks early and twins.
Forgot to ask if they are identical of fraternal twins?
Hope you are doing better today!!  I am praying for you!

I went in yesterday morning for an emergency d and c due to heavy bleeding the night before. We were just afraid there would also be more blood clots. I have had a difficult 2 months with cramping and spotting, and I was getting so emotionally attached so early, Part of me is relieved that I didn't have to make this decision.This has been the biggest emotional rollercoaster I have ever been on, and I feel a connection with every one on this forum. I still want to check in and see how everyone is doing! I hope that's okay!Summer, your girls are beautiful!!!
I am so sorry to hear your news.  I am glad that God took the decision out of your hands.  I know how torn you were about this.  The most important thing is you are Ok!  Take care of yourself ~Julie
Girls, continue to hang in there, we need more happy endings!
You didn't have to have hysterectomy, I am so suprised.  Did they say another pregnancy is possible?
Look at the profiles of all the members.  Thats all I can say.  ALL the members.Creepy.

I am so confused!  Of course I am a small town backwoods girl not a big shot from CA but what scenario are you speaking of?  Pregnancy after ablation? I am just curious when there are those of us out here looking for answers and some support under some very scary circumstances why you as a "L&D nurse" would not understand the seriousness of the situation.  Maybe I have taken you all wrong!!  Please explain!

Back to business :o) I'm so sorry to hear about what happened. I am glad to see you're OK! Hang in there girl and don't let this stop you from your goals! :o)Summer: Those babies are beautiful. Good for you!Hang in there ladies!Stacy

I am even more confused now than I was earlier.  I logged back into my computer pulled up my favorites and the old forum came up.  Now I can't even see the horrible conversation that was going on earlier.  Very weird!!

This is a thread, not a forum. If you scroll up to the very top of this page, and click on the link that says "Back to Forum," THAT'S the Maternal & Child forum. This is a thread that is a part of this forum.Much of the conversation of yesterday violates MedHelp rules: fake posters, name-calling, people getting bent out of shape, etc. All those parts of this thread have been deleted.Hope this helps clarify some things for you. God bless.

Ladies, I just wanted to assure you that we are not trying to hijack this thread or cause drama.  I'm sure you are going through a lot and need each other's support.  We are just trying to make you aware that not all stories are true and to be very very careful.  Pay attention to details and consistency in someone's story.  If things are not making sense then question it.  I guarantee you once you call someone out on something they will disappear for good.  Good luck to all of you.

Ladies, please.  Lets keep the comments to the subject matter mentioned in the topic of the original post, please.I'm over this, its out of control.  The more you comment, the worse it's getting.  I shouldn't have made the comments I did yesterday.  I own that.Please...please.  Just stop.  I'm asking nicely.The subject of this post was pregnancy after an ablation.  Please, lets keep it that way.
Thank you very much!

I posted on the thread that Andi created but I just wanted some knowledge about endometrial ablation.  I've never heard of this before.  I googled it and read that many women undergo it if they have heavy periods?  Can someone for educational purposes give me some more information about it.  I'm very curious to know more.

question: Last year I had an ablation of the lining of my uterus. The dr. told me that I could'nt get pregnant. Over a year later, I am pregnant and scared to death. I have been reading up on ablation, and have came across nothing but "you should'nt get pregnant after an alation, because it's high risk for the mother and baby". I do not know how far along I am, but I believe about 4 mths already. I go to the dr. on Monday, but I was wondering has anyone heard of someone having an ablation and then getting pregnant and everything turned out great. Thank you for your time.Deanna ***@****
title: Pregnant after an ablation
